title: 104_hr79
content: The "Thurgood Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of 500,000 1 dollar silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will contain 90% silver and 10% copper, weigh 26.73 grams, and have a diameter of 1.500 inches. The silver for minting will be sourced from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize Thurgood Marshall's tenure on the Supreme Court, with inscriptions including the coin's value, the year 1995, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize Thurgood Marshall's tenure on the Supreme Court and will include inscriptions such as the coin's value, the year 1995, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties, including Thurgood Marshall, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins within a 1-year period starting 90 days after the Act's enactment. The Secretary will sell coins issued under the Act at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. The Secretary shall promptly pay all surcharges from coin sales to the Historical Preservation Committee of the Supreme Court Historical Society for collecting and preserving the physical history of the Supreme Court, including research, acquisition of objects and documents, and preservation of historical items. The Comptroller General of the United States shall conduct audits. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the books and records of the Supreme Court Historical Society related to expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
